selected_quotes: Our paper about effort influencing perceptual decisions is out! Thanks to everyone who helped me through.@elife
'perceptual decisions are biased by the cost to act' - v interesting results from hagura, haggard and diedrichsen
Perceptual decisions are biased by the cost to act. More evidence of biases in perceptual choices!
Effort to act can bias perceptual decisions. Neat study Hagura, Haggard, Diedrichsen in @eLife
People bias their decisions away from those that require the most effort, even if they are unaware of the extra cost

citation.abstract: Perceptual decisions are classically thought to depend mainly on the stimulus characteristics, probability and associated reward. However, in many cases, the motor response is considered to be a neutral output channel that only reflects the upstream decision. Contrary to this view, we show that perceptual decisions can be recursively influenced by the physical resistance applied to the response. When participants reported the direction of the visual motion by left or right manual reaching movement with different resistances, their reports were biased towards the direction associated with less effortful option. Repeated exposure to such resistance on hand during perceptual judgements also biased subsequent judgements using voice, indicating that effector-dependent motor costs not only biases the report at the stage of motor response, but also changed how the sensory inputs are transformed into decisions. This demonstrates that the cost to act can influence our decisions beyond the context of the specific action.
citation.title: Perceptual decisions are biased by the cost to act

news.title: We all tend to be a little lazy, and this new study explains why
news.summary: If you feel like you don’t want to complete more difficult tasks, a new study suggests why: Our brains may tend to opt for the easier solution — even if we’re not actively aware of it.

news.title: Humans are hard-wired to follow the path of least resistance
news.summary: The amount of effort required to do something influences what we think we see, finds a new UCL study suggesting we're biased towards perceiving anything challenging to be less appealing.

news.title: Humans are hard-wired to follow the path of least resistance
news.summary: It is an approach best summed up by Homer Simpson, who told his son Bart 'If something is hard to do, then it's not worth doing'.

news.title: Path of least resistance is hard wired, say researchers
news.summary: We are biased towards perceiving anything challenging to be less appealing, suggests a new study from University College London.

news.title: Human Brain Perceives Challenges as Less Appealing
news.summary: Traditionally, scientists have assumed the visual system gives us perceptual information, and the motor system is a mere downstream output channel, which expresses our decision based on what we saw, without actually influencing the decision itself.

news.title: PSYCHO : Et si nous étions câblés pour la facilité ? – eLife
news.summary: En général, les humains n’aiment pas trop le challenge, et leur cerveau est câblé pour suivre la voie la plus aisée, conclut cette étude de l’Université de Londres.

author.name: Neuroscience RSS Feeds - Neuroscience News Updates
author.description: Neuroscience RSS feeds from NeuroscienceNews.com provide breaking neuroscience news from the cutting edge of neuroscience. All Neuroscience News articles are hand picked, so all neuroscience articles listed are sure to be directly related to neuroscience. Suggest new articles at neurosciencenews.com if you believe an article would be important to the neuroscience community.

blogs.title: What we perceive depends on how much it costs us.
blogs.summary: Interesting work from Hagura et al.  showing that our perceptual decisions are biased by the action costs that are associated with our subsequent decisions is summarized by de Lange and Fritsche:  Perceptual decision-making is not solely determined by the

facebook.title: Picking the easy option – Brains and Behaviour – Medium
facebook.summary:
Does an apple at the top of the tree look more or less tempting than the low-hanging fruit?

Evidence suggests that the effort required to act on a decision can influence the decision itself. Find out more in this eLife digest: medium.com/brains-and-behavi
